Title: Cardiac Rehabilitation for Older Patients Abstract: To the Editor: In the Physical Activity Intervention in Elderly Patients with Myocardial Infarction (PIpELINe) trial, Tonet and colleagues (Sept. 11 issue)1 found that a rehabilitation intervention resulted in a lower incidence of cardiovascular death or unplanned cardiovascular hospitalization within 1 year than usual care among older... Full Article:
nejm N Engl J Med New England Journal of Medicine 0028-4793 1533-4406 Massachusetts Medical Society 10.1056/NEJMc2514544 NJ202511273932121 Correspondence Cardiac Rehabilitation for Older Patients 27112025November 27, 2025 39321 21732175 Copyright © 2025 Massachusetts Medical Society. All rights reserved. 2025 Massachusetts Medical Society

To the Editor: In the Physical Activity Intervention in Elderly Patients with Myocardial Infarction (PIpELINe) trial, Tonet and colleagues (Sept. 11 issue)1 found that a rehabilitation intervention resulted in a lower incidence of cardiovascular death or unplanned cardiovascular hospitalization within 1 year than usual care among older patients with myocardial infarction. Although the results of this trial are commendable, it has certain limitations. First, the trial population was relatively fit and excluded patients with cognitive impairment, which could potentially limit the applicability of findings to frail older adults. Second, because the trial was conducted in a single country, with underrepresentation . . .

 CMEno Freeno Rehab Bint E. Tahir, M.B., B.S., Hazrat Bari Imam Sarkar Medical and Dental College, Islamabad, Pakistan Syeda Midhat, M.B., B.S., Rubia Afzal, M.B., B.S., Jinnah Sindh Medical University, Karachi, Pakistan 21732174

To the Editor: In the Physical Activity Intervention in Elderly Patients with Myocardial Infarction (PIpELINe) trial, Tonet and colleagues (Sept. 11 issue)1 found that a rehabilitation intervention resulted in a lower incidence of cardiovascular death or unplanned cardiovascular hospitalization within 1 year than usual care among older patients with myocardial infarction. Although the results of this trial are commendable, it has certain limitations.

First, the trial population was relatively fit and excluded patients with cognitive impairment, which could potentially limit the applicability of findings to frail older adults. Second, because the trial was conducted in a single country, with underrepresentation of women and no reporting of race or ethnic group, the results may not fully translate to more diverse populations.2,3 Third, the trial was conducted during the Covid-19 pandemic, a period that substantially affected hospitalization patterns and outpatient care. Fourth, the intervention required an intensive use of resources, and the absence of a cost-effectiveness analysis raises concern about feasibility in routine clinical practice.4 Finally, adherence to medical therapy was not rigorously assessed, and closer supervision in the intervention group may itself have influenced outcomes.5 Future research should address these limitations to improve generalizability and implementation.

Rehab Bint E. Tahir can be contacted at rehabtahir363@gmail.com.

No potential conflict of interest relevant to this letter was reported.

 Tonet E, Raisi A, Zagnoni S, et al. Multidomain rehabilitation for older patients with myocardial infarction. N Engl J Med 2025;393:973-982.40879431 Jiang H, Wong JJ, Tan R-S, et al. Effect of frailty on cardiovascular clinical trials: a systematic review and meta-analysis. JACC Adv 2025;4:101889-101889.40555009 Ya’qoub L, Lemor A, Dabbagh M, et al. Racial, ethnic, and sex disparities in patients with STEMI and cardiogeni

All rights reserved. 2025 Massachusetts Medical Society

To the Editor: In the Physical Activity Intervention in Elderly Patients with Myocardial Infarction (PIpELINe) trial, Tonet and colleagues (Sept. 11 issue)1 found that a rehabilitation intervention resulted in a lower incidence of cardiovascular death or unplanned cardiovascular hospitalization within 1 year than usual care among older patients with myocardial infarction. Although the results of this trial are commendable, it has certain limitations. First, the trial population was relatively fit and excluded patients with cognitive impairment, which could potentially limit the applicability of findings to frail older adults. Second, because the trial was conducted in a single country, with underrepresentation . . .

 CMEno Freeno Rehab Bint E. Tahir, M.B., B.S., Hazrat Bari Imam Sarkar Medical and Dental College, Islamabad, Pakistan Syeda Midhat, M.B., B.S., Rubia Afzal, M.B., B.S., Jinnah Sindh Medical University, Karachi, Pakistan 21732174

To the Editor: In the Physical Activity Intervention in Elderly Patients with Myocardial Infarction (PIpELINe) trial, Tonet and colleagues (Sept. 11 issue)1 found that a rehabilitation intervention resulted in a lower incidence of cardiovascular death or unplanned cardiovascular hospitalization within 1 year than usual care among older patients with myocardial infarction. Although the results of this trial are commendable, it has certain limitations.

First, the trial population was relatively fit and excluded patients with cognitive impairment, which could potentially limit the applicability of findings to frail older adults. Second, because the trial was conducted in a single country, with underrepresentation of women and no reporting of race or ethnic group, the results may not fully translate to more diverse populations.2,3 Third, the trial was conducted during the Covid-19 pandemic, a period that substantially affected hospitalization patterns and outpatient care. Fourth, the intervention required an intensive use of resources, and the absence of a cost-effectiveness analysis raises concern about feasibility in routine clinical practice.4 Finally, adherence to medical therapy was not rigorously assessed, and closer supervision in the intervention group may itself have influenced outcomes.5 Future research should address these limitations to improve generalizability and implementation.

Rehab Bint E. Tahir can be contacted at rehabtahir363@gmail.com.

No potential conflict of interest relevant to this letter was reported.

 Tonet E, Raisi A, Zagnoni S, et al. Multidomain rehabilitation for older patients with myocardial infarction. N Engl J Med 2025;393:973-982.40879431 Jiang H, Wong JJ, Tan R-S, et al. Effect of frailty on cardiovascular clinical trials: a systematic review and meta-analysis. JACC Adv 2025;4:101889-101889.40555009 Ya’qoub L, Lemor A, Dabbagh M, et al. Racial, ethnic, and sex disparities in patients with STEMI and cardiogenic shock. JACC Cardiovasc Interv 2021;14:653-660.33736772 Shepard DS, Zakir S, Gaalema DE, Ades PA. Cost-effectiveness of cardiac rehabilitation in older adults with coronary heart disease. J Cardiopulm Rehabil Prev 2024;44:107-114.37820288 Garcia RA, Spertus JA, Benton MC, et al. Association of medication adherence with health outcomes in the ISCHEMIA trial. J Am Coll Cardiol 2022;80:755-765.35981820 Chen Die Yang, M.D., Ph.D., Xiao Qun Wang, M.D., Ph.D., Ruijin Hospital Affiliated to Shanghai Jiao Tong University School of Medicine, Shanghai 21742174

To the Editor: We have several concerns regarding the PIpELINe trial by Tonet et al. First, the primary outcome was driven mainly by a substantial reduction in unplanned hospitalizations for heart failure. However, baseline assessments omitted crucial measures of cardiac injury and heart-failure severity, such as peak levels of troponin and natriuretic peptides, along with infarct size,1 with data provided only on left ventricular ejection fraction. This omission is meaningful, because potential imbalances in these key prognostic factors may have confounded the results. Second, the control group received only a single 30-minute counseling session. This minimal-contact comparator is insufficient to control for the effects of increased professional attention, which introduces a high potential for performance bias and potentially overestimates the treatment effect. Third, although the authors acknowledge the challenge of isolating the effects of the components of the intervention, this limitation has important clinical implications.2 It remains unclear which element (exercise, diet, or risk-factor management) drove the large reduction in heart-failure admissions. The clarification of this point is essential for developing targeted, resource-efficient strategies.

Xiao Qun Wang can be contacted at wangxq@shsmu.edu.cn.

No potential conflict of interest relevant to this letter was reported.

 Byrne RA, Rossello X, Coughlan JJ, et al. 2023 ESC guidelines for the management of acute coronary syndromes. Eur Heart J 2023;44:3720-3826.37622654 Craig P, Dieppe P, Macintyre S, et al. Developing and evaluating complex interventions: the new Medical Research Council guidance. BMJ 2008;337:a1655-a1655.18824488 Elisabetta Tonet, M.D., Gianluca Campo, M.D., Azienda Ospedaliero–Universitaria di Ferrara, Ferrara, Italy 21742175

The authors reply: In response to Tahir and colleagues: we agree that the generalizability of our findings is paramount. The inclusion of cognitively intact patients was a deliberate design choice for this initial efficacy trial because it was aimed at establishing proof-of-concept of our premise under optimal conditions. Although our cohort was predominantly White (so the generalizability of our findings to other racial or ethnic groups needs further confirmation), a notable strength was the enrollment of a larger proportion of women than the percentages in many contemporary trials that included patients after myocardial infarction,1,2 a factor that enhances the relevance of our findings for this demographic population.

The point regarding the Covid-19 pandemic is well taken.3 We contend that showing the efficacy of the intervention despite this period of profound systemic disruption underscores its robustness and adaptability. Any pandemic-related effects were equally distributed between the randomized groups, thus preserving the internal validity of our comparison. Our program appears to be low-cost in our health system, since it was anchored by only a few initial supervised sessions followed by monthly reinforcement. This structure enhances its potential for widespread adoption. Adherence was rigorously assessed at each scheduled outpatient visit. The positive effect of supervision is not a confounder but an integral, operational component of how successful multidomain rehabilitation functions.

In response to Yang and Wang: our comparator, the single structured counseling session plus standard care, reflects the real-world practice in many systems, a choice that has been mirrored in other pragmatic trials.4 It is critical to note that the patients in both groups received routine, guideline-directed follow-up from their primary care physicians and cardiologists. This design robustly tests the incremental value of our intensive program over conventional, high-quality care. Finally, we did assess biomarkers (e.g., brain natriuretic peptide and troponin) at baseline, although these data were not a primary focus of our analysis. As expected in a large, randomized trial, the distribution of these biomarkers appeared to be well balanced between groups, a finding that was consistent with what was observed across all other baseline characteristics reported in the trial. We concur that deconstructing the intervention is a vital next step; further analyses are currently being conducted to better understand the role of each component in the observed clinical benefit.

Gianluca Campo can be contacted at cmpglc@unife.it.

Since publication of the article, the authors report no further potential conflict of interest.

 Ibanez B, Latini R, Rossello X, et al. Beta-blockers after myocardial infarction without reduced ejection fraction. N Engl J Med 2025;393:1889-1900. Munkhaugen J, Kristensen AMD, Halvorsen S, et al. Beta-blockers after myocardial infarction in patients without heart failure. N Engl J Med 2025;393:1901-1911. Campo G, Fortuna D, Berti E, et al. In- and out-of-hospital mortality for myocardial infarction during the first wave of the COVID-19 pandemic in Emilia-Romagna, Italy: a population-based observational study. Lancet Reg Health Eur 2021;3:100055-100055.34557800 Kitzman DW, Whellan DJ, Duncan P, et al. Physical rehabilitation for older patients hospitalized for heart failure. N Engl J Med 2021;385:203-216.33999544

title: Small Steps, Big Ventricles: Idiopathic Normal-Pressure Hydrocephalus

 1Neurology/Neurosurgery 1_1Neurology/Neurosurgery General 1_4Dementia/Alzheimer Disease 1_13Confusion/Delirium 3Surgery 3_1Surgery General 7Psychiatry 7_1Psychiatry General 10Emergency Medicine 10_1Emergency Medicine General 15Geriatrics/Aging 15_1Geriatrics/Aging General 15_4Dementia/Alzheimer Disease 23Urology/Prostate Disease 23_2Urinary Incontinence 28Clinical Medicine 28_1Clinical Medicine General 28_2Hospital-Based Clinical Medicine CMEno Freeno release-date-display-string2025-09-16T11:00:00-04:00

After 60 years of cogitation about normal-pressure hydrocephalus, the results of a worthy randomized trial that assessed the effects of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shunting are now published in the Journal.1 No one seems to want to own idiopathic normal-pressure hydrocephalus. The symptoms are neurologic, the treatment is neurosurgical, and the cause is not known. Skepticism about its very existence has been expressed by experienced neurologists,2 and even the term “normal” is ambiguous, given that the CSF pressure is frequently mildly elevated. Normal-pressure hydrocephalus was brought to wide attention by an article published in the Journal in 19653 that acknowledged the formative work of the Colombian neurosurgeon S. Hakim, and current concepts of the disorder are presented in a review by Johnson and Williams,4 also in the current issue.

The canonical triad of symptoms in normal-pressure hydrocephalus is subacute gait disturbance, cognitive impairment, and urinary urgency or incontinence in older adults with enlarged lateral ventricles. This description circumscribes the disorder but does not adequately express how exasperating it is to make the diagnosis and how frequently the disorder is a cause of gait problems in older adults. Most affected persons present with wide-based, slow, short-stepped gait and imbalance. At this stage, clinical experience indicates that CSF drainage, usually through shunting from the ventricles to the peritoneum, improves walking in most patients and decreases the chances of subsequent dementia and incontinence. The reason for shunting is to reduce ventricular size and relieve stretching of the overlying white-matter tracts, although the genesis of symptoms probably involves more complicated mechanisms. Later stages of the disorder are not as amenable to shunting.

Measures of the size of ventricles and of CSF dynamics have had periods of popularity for diagnosing normal-pressure hydrocephalus and predicting a response to shunting. One widely adopted method is determining whether gait improves after drainage tests are performed (i.e., after removal of a large volume of CSF through lumbar puncture or through an indwelling lumbar catheter over 2 to 3 days). These drainage tests create some circularity by defining the disorder not according to cardinal clinical features but according to response to treatment. Deriving a benefit from test drainage may stack the deck in favor of a response to permanent shunting, but improvement in gait after CSF drainage was justifiable as an entry criterion in the current trial.

The results of the trial affirm the existence of idiopathic normal-pressure hydrocephalus as a clinical entity and foremost show that CSF drainage is usually effective. Three months after participants underwent shunting, gait velocity improved by a mean of 0.23 m per second in the group with an open-valve shunt setting and was essentially unchanged in the placebo group, which had a valve setting that precluded drainage. The change in gait velocity in the open-shunt group was within a meaningful range and was supported by a substantially greater improvement in scores on a measure of overall mobility and impressively fewer falls than in the placebo group.

Clinicians are often vexed by the lack of improvement after shunting even after successful test drainage (and improvement that sometimes occurs without shunting). This problem was also evident in the trial. According to a threshold for improvement of at least 0.10 m per second, gait worsened minimally in approximately 20% of the participants in the open-shunt group (and improved in a similar percentage in the placebo group). Also, there was ostensibly no difference between groups in cognition — perhaps because both started with performance suggesting mild cognitive impairment at baseline or because 3 months was too brief to show change. I encourage readers to look at these score results in Table 3 and make their own judgments.

Because participants were eligible for enrollment if they could walk 10 m without the assistance of another person and if gait velocity improved after test drainage, the findings apply with certainty only in these circumstances. The trial does not address what to do if the result of test drainage is ambiguous in a patient with typical clinical and imaging findings of normal-pressure hydrocephalus, which is a common issue in practice.

Adverse effects of shunting are to be expected. Principal among these effects is subdural hematoma, which occurred in 12% of the participants in the open-shunt group, and orthostatic headache, which occurred in 59%. The clinical significance of the subdural hematomas is unclear. C. Miller Fisher, an astute neurologist, claimed that subdural collections could actually be beneficial by preventing re-expansion of the ventricles.5 These complications are often fixed by adjusting the shunt valve, but they may warrant surgery, so they should not be minimized. One participant in the placebo group died after a cerebral hemorrhage that occurred during shunt surgery.

The authors will determine the durability of the effect of shunting on gait and examine the effect on cognition at 12 months. Gait improvement could wane. The current results are a signature advance given that no truly equivalent trials have been performed.

This editorial was published on September 16, 2025, at NEJM.org.

Disclosure forms provided by the author are available with the full text of this editorial at NEJM.org.

 Disclosure Forms Luciano MG, Williams MA, Hamilton MG, et al. A randomized trial of shunting for idiopathic normal-pressure hydrocephalus. N Engl J Med 2025;393:2198-2209. Saper CB. Is there even such a thing as “Idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus”? Ann Neurol 2017;82:514-515.28940258 Adams RD, Fisher CM, Hakim S, Ojemann RG, Sweet WH. Symptomatic occult hydrocephalus with “normal” cerebrospinal-fluid pressure: a treatable syndrome. N Engl J Med 1965;273:117-126.14303656 Johnson MD, Williams MA. Idiopathic normal-pressure hydrocephalus. N Engl J Med 2025;393:2243-2253. Fisher CM. Reversal of normal pressure hydrocephalus symptoms by subdural collections. Can J Neurol Sci 2002;29:171-174.12035840

 1Neurology/Neurosurgery 1_1Neurology/Neurosurgery General 1_4Dementia/Alzheimer Disease 1_13Confusion/Delirium 3Surgery 3_1Surgery General 7Psychiatry 7_1Psychiatry General 10Emergency Medicine 10_1Emergency Medicine General 15Geriatrics/Aging 15_1Geriatrics/Aging General 15_4Dementia/Alzheimer Disease 23Urology/Prostate Disease 23_2Urinary Incontinence 28Clinical Medicine 28_1Clinical Medicine General 28_2Hospital-Based Clinical Medicine CMEno Freeno release-date-display-string2025-09-16T11:00:00-04:00

After 60 years of cogitation about normal-pressure hydrocephalus, the results of a worthy randomized trial that assessed the effects of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shunting are now published in the Journal.1 No one seems to want to own idiopathic normal-pressure hydrocephalus. The symptoms are neurologic, the treatment is neurosurgical, and the cause is not known. Skepticism about its very existence has been expressed by experienced neurologists,2 and even the term “normal” is ambiguous, given that the CSF pressure is frequently mildly elevated. Normal-pressure hydrocephalus was brought to wide attention by an article published in the Journal in 19653 that acknowledged the formative work of the Colombian neurosurgeon S. Hakim, and current concepts of the disorder are presented in a review by Johnson and Williams,4 also in the current issue.

The canonical triad of symptoms in normal-pressure hydrocephalus is subacute gait disturbance, cognitive impairment, and urinary urgency or incontinence in older adults with enlarged lateral ventricles. This description circumscribes the disorder but does not adequately express how exasperating it is to make the diagnosis and how frequently the disorder is a cause of gait problems in older adults. Most affected persons present with wide-based, slow, short-stepped gait and imbalance. At this stage, clinical experience indicates that CSF drainage, usually through shunting from the ventricles to the peritoneum, improves walking in most patients and decreases the chances of subsequent dementia and incontinence. The reason for shunting is to reduce ventricular size and relieve stretching of the overlying white-matter tracts, although the genesis of symptoms probably involves more complicated mechanisms. Later stages of the disorder are not as amenable to shunting.

Measures of the size of ventricles and of CSF dynamics have had periods of popularity for diagnosing normal-pressure hydrocephalus and predicting a response to shunting. One widely adopted method is determining whether gait improves after drainage tests are performed (i.e., after removal of a large volume of CSF through lumbar puncture or through an indwelling lumbar catheter over 2 to 3 days). These drainage tests create some circularity by defining the disorder not according to cardinal clinical features but according to response to treatment. Deriving a benefit from test drainage may stack the deck in favor of a response to permanent shunting, but improvement in gait after CSF drainage was justifiable as an entry criterion in the current trial.

The results of the trial affirm the existence of idiopathic normal-pressure hydrocephalus as a clinical entity and foremost show that CSF drainage is usually effective. Three months after participants underwent shunting, gait velocity improved by a mean of 0.23 m per second in the group with an open-valve shunt setting and was essentially unchanged in the placebo group, which had a valve setting that precluded drainage. The change in gait velocity in the open-shunt group was within a meaningful range and was supported by a substantially greater improvement in scores on a measure of overall mobility and impressively fewer falls than in the placebo group.

Clinicians are often vexed by the lack of improvement after shunting even after successful test drainage (and improvement that sometimes occurs without shunting). This problem was also evident in the trial. According to a threshold for improvement of at least 0.10 m per second, gait worsened minimally in approximately 20% of the participants in the open-shunt group (and improved in a similar percentage in the placebo group). Also, there was ostensibly no difference between groups in cognition — perhaps because both started with performance suggesting mild cognitive impairment at baseline or because 3 months was too brief to show change. I encourage readers to look at these score results in Table 3 and make their own judgments.

Because participants were eligible for enrollment if they could walk 10 m without the assistance of another person and if gait velocity improved after test drainage, the findings apply with certainty only in these circumstances. The trial does not address what to do if the result of test drainage is ambiguous in a patient with typical clinical and imaging findings of normal-pressure hydrocephalus, which is a common issue in practice.

Adverse effects of shunting are to be expected. Principal among these effects is subdural hematoma, which occurred in 12% of the participants in the open-shunt group, and orthostatic headache, which occurred in 59%. The clinical significance of the subdural hematomas is unclear. C. Miller Fisher, an astute neurologist, claimed that subdural collections could actually be beneficial by preventing re-expansion of the ventricles.5 These complications are often fixed by adjusting the shunt valve, but they may warrant surgery, so they should not be minimized. One participant in the placebo group died after a cerebral hemorrhage that occurred during shunt surgery.

The authors will determine the durability of the effect of shunting on gait and examine the effect on cognition at 12 months. Gait improvement could wane. The current results are a signature advance given that no truly equivalent trials have been performed.

This editorial was published on September 16, 2025, at NEJM.org.

Disclosure forms provided by the author are available with the full text of this editorial at NEJM.org.

 Disclosure Forms Luciano MG, Williams MA, Hamilton MG, et al. A randomized trial of shunting for idiopathic normal-pressure hydrocephalus. N Engl J Med 2025;393:2198-2209. Saper CB. Is there even such a thing as “Idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus”? Ann Neurol 2017;82:514-515.28940258 Adams RD, Fisher CM, Hakim S, Ojemann RG, Sweet WH. Symptomatic occult hydrocephalus with “normal” cerebrospinal-fluid pressure: a treatable syndrome. N Engl J Med 1965;273:117-126.14303656 Johnson MD, Williams MA. Idiopathic normal-pressure hydrocephalus. N Engl J Med 2025;393:2243-2253. Fisher CM. Reversal of normal pressure hydrocephalus symptoms by subdural collections. Can J Neurol Sci 2002;29:171-174.12035840

title: Oral Semaglutide in Adults with Overweight or Obesity
abstract: To the Editor: In the Oral Semaglutide Treatment Effect in People with Obesity (OASIS) 4 trial, Wharton et al. content:
Title: Oral Semaglutide in Adults with Overweight or Obesity Abstract: To the Editor: In the Oral Semaglutide Treatment Effect in People with Obesity (OASIS) 4 trial, Wharton et al. (Sept. 18 issue)1 found that oral semaglutide at a dose of 25 mg produced substantial weight loss in adults with overweight or obesity. Although this intermediate dose broadens... Full Article:
nejm N Engl J Med New England Journal of Medicine 0028-4793 1533-4406 Massachusetts Medical Society 10.1056/NEJMc2515109 NJ202512113932321 Correspondence Oral Semaglutide in Adults with Overweight or Obesity 11122025December 11, 2025 39323 23812383 Copyright © 2025 Massachusetts Medical Society. All rights reserved. 2025 Massachusetts Medical Society

To the Editor: In the Oral Semaglutide Treatment Effect in People with Obesity (OASIS) 4 trial, Wharton et al. (Sept. 18 issue)1 found that oral semaglutide at a dose of 25 mg produced substantial weight loss in adults with overweight or obesity. Although this intermediate dose broadens therapeutic options, several issues merit attention. The absence of an active-comparator group limits assessment of relative efficacy against the 50-mg oral or 2.4-mg subcutaneous formulations. Moreover, the trial cohort was predominantly White and female, which limits generalizability to populations disproportionately affected by obesity. Although 94.5% of the participants overall attended the final visit . . .

 CMEno Freeno Mohammad Kermansaravi, M.D., Iran University of Medical Sciences, Tehran Ricardo V. Cohen, M.D., Hospital Alemão Oswaldo Cruz, São Paulo 23812382

To the Editor: In the Oral Semaglutide Treatment Effect in People with Obesity (OASIS) 4 trial, Wharton et al. (Sept. 18 issue)1 found that oral semaglutide at a dose of 25 mg produced substantial weight loss in adults with overweight or obesity. Although this intermediate dose broadens therapeutic options, several issues merit attention. The absence of an active-comparator group limits assessment of relative efficacy against the 50-mg oral or 2.4-mg subcutaneous formulations. Moreover, the trial cohort was predominantly White and female, which limits generalizability to populations disproportionately affected by obesity.

Although 94.5% of the participants overall attended the final visit at 71 weeks, 18.5% of the participants in the semaglutide group had discontinued treatment by 64 weeks, mainly because of gastrointestinal adverse events, especially nausea (in 46.6% of the participants) and vomiting (in 30.9%). Such discontinuation suggests that effectiveness may be attenuated in clinical practice. Dysesthesia, which was reported in 4.9% of the participants, although mild or moderate, arouses mechanistic concerns about glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonism and the absorption enhancer unique to the oral formulation — findings not observed with injectable semaglutide.2 Despite a mean change in body weight from baseline to week 64 of −13.6%, reductions in blood pressure were minimal and nonsignificant, in contrast with findings in previous trials of GLP-1 receptor agonists.3,4 Given the chronic nature of obesity, longer-term randomized trials and observational studies are needed to establish the durability, safety, and cardiometabolic benefit of oral semaglutide therapy.

Mohammad Kermansaravi can be contacted at mkermansaravi@yahoo.com.

No potential conflict of interest relevant to this letter was reported.

 Wharton S, Lingvay I, Bogdanski P, et al. Oral semaglutide at a dose of 25 mg in adults with overweight or obesity. N Engl J Med 2025;393:1077-1087.40934115 Shetty R, Basheer FT, Poojari PG, Thunga G, Chandran VP, Acharya LD. Adverse drug reactions of GLP-1 agonists: a systematic review of case reports. Diabetes Metab Syndr 2022;16:102427-102427.35217468 Liakos CI, Papadopoulos

All rights reserved. 2025 Massachusetts Medical Society

To the Editor: In the Oral Semaglutide Treatment Effect in People with Obesity (OASIS) 4 trial, Wharton et al. (Sept. 18 issue)1 found that oral semaglutide at a dose of 25 mg produced substantial weight loss in adults with overweight or obesity. Although this intermediate dose broadens therapeutic options, several issues merit attention. The absence of an active-comparator group limits assessment of relative efficacy against the 50-mg oral or 2.4-mg subcutaneous formulations. Moreover, the trial cohort was predominantly White and female, which limits generalizability to populations disproportionately affected by obesity. Although 94.5% of the participants overall attended the final visit . . .

 CMEno Freeno Mohammad Kermansaravi, M.D., Iran University of Medical Sciences, Tehran Ricardo V. Cohen, M.D., Hospital Alemão Oswaldo Cruz, São Paulo 23812382

To the Editor: In the Oral Semaglutide Treatment Effect in People with Obesity (OASIS) 4 trial, Wharton et al. (Sept. 18 issue)1 found that oral semaglutide at a dose of 25 mg produced substantial weight loss in adults with overweight or obesity. Although this intermediate dose broadens therapeutic options, several issues merit attention. The absence of an active-comparator group limits assessment of relative efficacy against the 50-mg oral or 2.4-mg subcutaneous formulations. Moreover, the trial cohort was predominantly White and female, which limits generalizability to populations disproportionately affected by obesity.

Although 94.5% of the participants overall attended the final visit at 71 weeks, 18.5% of the participants in the semaglutide group had discontinued treatment by 64 weeks, mainly because of gastrointestinal adverse events, especially nausea (in 46.6% of the participants) and vomiting (in 30.9%). Such discontinuation suggests that effectiveness may be attenuated in clinical practice. Dysesthesia, which was reported in 4.9% of the participants, although mild or moderate, arouses mechanistic concerns about glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonism and the absorption enhancer unique to the oral formulation — findings not observed with injectable semaglutide.2 Despite a mean change in body weight from baseline to week 64 of −13.6%, reductions in blood pressure were minimal and nonsignificant, in contrast with findings in previous trials of GLP-1 receptor agonists.3,4 Given the chronic nature of obesity, longer-term randomized trials and observational studies are needed to establish the durability, safety, and cardiometabolic benefit of oral semaglutide therapy.

Mohammad Kermansaravi can be contacted at mkermansaravi@yahoo.com.

No potential conflict of interest relevant to this letter was reported.

 Wharton S, Lingvay I, Bogdanski P, et al. Oral semaglutide at a dose of 25 mg in adults with overweight or obesity. N Engl J Med 2025;393:1077-1087.40934115 Shetty R, Basheer FT, Poojari PG, Thunga G, Chandran VP, Acharya LD. Adverse drug reactions of GLP-1 agonists: a systematic review of case reports. Diabetes Metab Syndr 2022;16:102427-102427.35217468 Liakos CI, Papadopoulos DP, Sanidas EA, et al. Blood pressure-lowering effect of newer antihyperglycemic agents (SGLT-2 Inhibitors, GLP-1 receptor agonists, and DPP-4 inhibitors). Am J Cardiovasc Drugs 2021;21:123-137.32780214 Kanbay M, Yayci E, Genc C, et al. From pathophysiology to novel approaches for obesity-associated hypertension. Clin Kidney J 2025;18(8):sfaf218-sfaf218.40761303 Hongquan Liu, M.D., Fengze Sun, M.D., Jitao Wu, M.D., Affiliated Yantai Yuhuangding Hospital of Qingdao University, Yantai, China 23822382

To the Editor: We have several concerns about the OASIS 4 trial by Wharton et al., which showed substantial weight reduction with 25 mg of oral semaglutide as compared with placebo at week 64 (−13.6% vs. −2.2%). First, long-term cardiovascular outcomes were not reported, despite the fact that cardiovascular disease is the primary cause of death in obesity.1 The 71-week duration of the trial allowed for insights about short-term safety but not about sustained risk, despite the cardioprotective effects of injectable GLP-1 receptor agonists that were seen in the SELECT (Semaglutide Effects on Cardiovascular Outcomes in People with Overweight or Obesity) trial.1

Second, subgroup data for patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) were omitted. A study by Abasheva et al.2 on GLP-1 receptor agonists in patients with CKD with overweight or obesity showed that GLP-1 metabolism and efficacy correlated with kidney function, thus necessitating clinical attention to the dose level, yet response to 25 mg of oral semaglutide in this patient population remains unclear.

Third, no data on interactions with common drugs, including angiotensin-converting–enzyme inhibitors and statins, were provided. Patients with obesity take these medications for hypertension, with or without dyslipidemia, and the delay in gastric emptying with semaglutide impairs absorption.3 Finally, the extension study of the STEP (Semaglutide Treatment Effect in People with Obesity) trial showed rebound in body weight after the cessation of GLP-1 therapy. Disclosing such trajectories would set realistic patient expectations.4

Jitao Wu can be contacted at yjwlurology@163.com.

Hongquan Liu and Fengze Sun contributed equally to this letter.

No potential conflict of interest relevant to this letter was reported.

 Lincoff AM, Brown-Frandsen K, Colhoun HM, et al. Semaglutide and cardiovascular outcomes in obesity without diabetes. N Engl J Med 2023;389:2221-2232.37952131 Abasheva D, Ortiz A, Fernandez-Fernandez B. GLP-1 receptor agonists in patients with chronic kidney disease and either overweight or obesity. Clin Kidney J 2024;17:Suppl 2:19-35.39583142 Langeskov EK, Kristensen K. Population pharmacokinetic of paracetamol and atorvastatin with co-administration of semaglutide. Pharmacol Res Perspect 2022;10(4):e00962-e00962.35799471 Wilding JPH, Batterham RL, Davies M, et al. Weight regain and cardiometabolic effects after withdrawal of semaglutide: the STEP 1 trial extension. Diabetes Obes Metab 2022;24:1553-1564.35441470 Sean Wharton, M.D., University of Toronto, Toronto Ruben Duque do Vale, M.D., Novo Nordisk, Søborg, Denmark W. Timothy Garvey, M.D., University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham 23832383

The authors reply: Kermansaravi and Cohen note the lack of an active-comparator group in our trial. The OASIS 4 trial was designed as a phase 3, placebo-controlled trial for regulatory approval. Head-to-head trials against active comparators are typically undertaken once efficacy and safety have been established in a placebo-controlled setting, as discussed in our article. Regarding generalizability, we acknowledge the imbalance in sex and note this as a limitation in the article. Sensitivity analyses that are presented in our Supplementary Appendix, which is available with the full text of our article at NEJM.org, showed that both race and ethnic group did not significantly modify the treatment effect. Treatment discontinuations in our trial were consistent with previous trials of GLP-1 receptor agonists in persons with obesity, and the treatment policy estimand that was used for the primary analysis captured the effects of semaglutide at a dose of 25 mg inclusive of participants who discontinued treatment.

All the adverse events, including dysesthesia, were mild to moderate in severity, and most had resolved by the end of the trial. Dysesthesia has been reported previously with subcutaneous semaglutide and appeared to be dose-related,1 indicating that it is not specific to the oral formulation. Reductions in blood pressure with oral semaglutide at a dose of 25 mg were similar to those seen in the OASIS 1 and STEP 1 trials.2,3 We agree that longer-term safety and cardiometabolic analyses of oral semaglutide at a dose of 25 mg would be informative; however, extensive in-trial data and studies of real-world evidence have shown the cardiometabolic benefits of semaglutide therapy.4,5

Liu and colleagues raise several points — namely, the lack of data on cardiovascular outcomes, CKD subgroup assessments, drug–drug interactions, and gastric emptying. These outcomes extend beyond the scope and objectives of this phase 3 trial that evaluated efficacy and safety. Long-term cardiovascular outcomes have been assessed in dedicated cardiovascular-outcome trials such as SELECT (which investigated subcutaneous semaglutide)4 and SOUL (the Semaglutide Cardiovascular Outcomes Trial, which investigated oral semaglutide).5 As we note in our Supplementary Appendix, participants with severe CKD were excluded from the OASIS 4 trial, and drug–drug interactions and gastric emptying are not routinely evaluated in phase 3 efficacy and safety studies. However, these variables have been assessed in earlier trials of oral semaglutide. Finally, although weight regain after treatment cessation has been reported with semaglutide, these analyses were undertaken in the STEP extension study and therefore were beyond the scope of primary analyses.

Sean Wharton can be contacted at sean@whartonmedicalclinic.com.

Since publication of the article, the authors report no further potential conflict of interest.

 Wharton S, Freitas P, Hjelmesæth J, et al. Once-weekly semaglutide 7·2 mg in adults with obesity (STEP UP): a randomised, controlled, phase 3b trial. Lancet Diabetes Endocrinol 2025;13:949-963.40961952 Knop FK, Aroda VR, do Vale RD, et al. Oral semaglutide 50 mg taken once per day in adults with overweight or obesity (OASIS 1): a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial. Lancet 2023;402:705-719.37385278 Wilding JPH, Batterham RL, Calanna S, et al. Once-weekly semaglutide in adults with overweight or obesity. N Engl J Med 2021;384:989-1002.33567185 Lincoff AM, Brown-Frandsen K, Colhoun HM, et al. Semaglutide and cardiovascular outcomes in obesity without diabetes. N Engl J Med 2023;389:2221-2232.37952131 McGuire DK, Marx N, Mulvagh SL, et al. Oral semaglutide and cardiovascular outcomes in high-risk type 2 diabetes. N Engl J Med 2025;392:2001-2012.40162642
